Insulin pen

data.Element: The ABASAGLAR cartridges are to be used only in conjunction with a Lilly reusable insulin pen (see section 4.4).
data.Text: The ABASAGLAR cartridges are to be used only in conjunction with a Lilly reusable insulin pen (see section 4.4).

data.Element: The pen should be used as recommended in the information provided with the device.

data.Element: The instructions for using the pen must be followed carefully for loading the cartridge, attaching the needle, and administering the insulin injection.
data.Text: The instructions for using the pen must be followed carefully for loading the cartridge, attaching the needle, and administering the insulin injection.

data.Element: If the insulin pen is damaged or not working properly (due to mechanical defects) it has to be discarded, and a new insulin pen has to be used.
data.Text: If the insulin pen is damaged or not working properly (due to mechanical defects) it has to be discarded, and a new insulin pen has to be used.
Cartridge

data.Element: Inspect the cartridge before use. It must only be used if the solution is clear, colourless, with no solid particles visible, and if it is of water-like consistency. Since ABASAGLAR is a solution, it does not require re-suspension before use. Air bubbles must be removed from the cartridge before injection (see instructions for using the pen).

Since ABASAGLAR is a solution, it does not require re-suspension before use. Air bubbles must be removed from the cartridge before injection (see instructions for using the pen).

data.Element: To prevent the possible transmission of disease, each pen must be used by one patient only.
data.Text: To prevent the possible transmission of disease, each pen must be used by one patient only.

data.Element: Empty cartridges must not be refilled and must be properly discarded. Insulin label must always be checked before each injection to avoid medication errors between insulin glargine and other insulins (see section 4.4).

data.Element: 4. CLINICAL PARTICULARS
data.Text: 4.       CLINICAL PARTICULARS
4.1     Therapeutic indications

data.Element: Treatment of diabetes mellitus in adults, adolescents and children aged 2 years and above.
data.Text: Treatment of diabetes mellitus in adults, adolescents and children aged 2 years and above.

data.Element: 4.2 Posology and method of administration
data.Text: 4.2     Posology and method of administration
Posology

data.Element: ABASAGLAR contains insulin glargine, an insulin analogue and has a prolonged duration of action.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR contains insulin glargine, an insulin analogue and has a prolonged duration of action.

data.Element: ABASAGLAR should be administered once daily at any time but at the same time each day.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR should be administered once daily at any time but at the same time each day.

data.Element: The dose regimen (dose and timing) should be individually adjusted. In patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, ABASAGLAR can also be given together with orally active antidiabetic medicinal products.
data.Text: The dose regimen (dose and timing) should be individually adjusted. In patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, ABASAGLAR can also be given together with orally active antidiabetic medicinal products.

data.Element: The potency of this medicinal product is stated in units. These units are exclusive to insulin glargine and are not the same as IU or the units used to express the potency of other insulin analogues (see section 5.1).
data.Text: The potency of this medicinal product is stated in units. These units are exclusive to insulin glargine and are not the same as IU or the units used to express the potency of other insulin analogues (see section 5.1).
Special populations
Elderly population (≥65 years old)

data.Element: In the elderly, progressive deterioration of renal function may lead to a steady decrease in insulin requirements.
data.Text: In the elderly, progressive deterioration of renal function may lead to a steady decrease in insulin requirements.
Renal impairment

data.Element: In patients with renal impairment, insulin requirements may be diminished due to reduced insulin metabolism.
data.Text: In patients with renal impairment, insulin requirements may be diminished due to reduced insulin metabolism.
Hepatic impairment

data.Element: In patients with hepatic impairment, insulin requirements may be diminished due to reduced capacity for gluconeogenesis and reduced insulin metabolism.
data.Text: In patients with hepatic impairment, insulin requirements may be diminished due to reduced capacity for gluconeogenesis and reduced insulin metabolism.
Paediatric population

data.Element: Adolescents and children aged 2 years and older
data.Text: Adolescents and children aged 2 years and older

data.Element: The safety and efficacy of insulin glargine have been established in adolescents and children aged 2 years and older (see section 5.1). The dose regimen (dose and timing) should be individually adjusted.
data.Text: The safety and efficacy of insulin glargine have been established in adolescents and children aged 2 years and older (see section 5.1). The dose regimen (dose and timing) should be individually adjusted.

data.Element: Children below 2 years of age
data.Text: Children below 2 years of age

data.Element: The safety and efficacy of insulin glargine have not been established. No data are available.
data.Text: The safety and efficacy of insulin glargine have not been established. No data are available.

data.Element: Switch from other insulins to ABASAGLAR
data.Text: Switch from other insulins to ABASAGLAR

data.Element: When switching from a treatment regimen with an intermediate or long-acting insulin to a regimen with ABASAGLAR, a change of the dose of the basal insulin may be required and the concomitant antidiabetic treatment may need to be adjusted (dose and timing of additional regular insulins or fast-acting insulin analogues or the dose of oral antidiabetic medicinal products).
data.Text: When switching from a treatment regimen with an intermediate or long-acting insulin to a regimen with ABASAGLAR, a change of the dose of the basal insulin may be required and the concomitant antidiabetic treatment may need to be adjusted (dose and timing of additional regular insulins or fast-acting insulin analogues or the dose of oral antidiabetic medicinal products).

data.Element: Switch from twice daily NPH insulin to ABASAGLAR
data.Text: Switch from twice daily NPH insulin to ABASAGLAR

data.Element: To reduce the risk of nocturnal and early morning hypoglycaemia, patients who are changing their basal insulin regimen from a twice daily NPH insulin to a once daily regimen with ABASAGLAR should reduce their daily dose of basal insulin by 20-30 % during the first weeks of treatment.
data.Text: To reduce the risk of nocturnal and early morning hypoglycaemia, patients who are changing their basal insulin regimen from a twice daily NPH insulin to a once daily regimen with ABASAGLAR should reduce their daily dose of basal insulin by 20-30 % during the first weeks of treatment.

data.Element: Switch from insulin glargine 300 units/ml to ABASAGLAR
data.Text: Switch from insulin glargine 300 units/ml to ABASAGLAR

data.Element: ABASAGLAR and Toujeo (insulin glargine 300 units/ml) are not bioequivalent and are not directly interchangeable. To reduce the risk of hypoglycemia, patients who are changing their basal insulin regimen from an insulin regimen with once daily insulin glargine 300 units/ml to a once daily regimen with ABASAGLAR should reduce their dose by approximately 20%.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR and Toujeo (insulin glargine 300 units/ml) are not bioequivalent and are not directly interchangeable. To reduce the risk of hypoglycemia, patients who are changing their basal insulin regimen from an insulin regimen with once daily insulin glargine 300 units/ml to a once daily regimen with ABASAGLAR should reduce their dose by approximately 20%.

data.Element: During the first weeks the reduction should, at least partially, be compensated by an increase in mealtime insulin, after this period the regimen should be adjusted individually.
data.Text: During the first weeks the reduction should, at least partially, be compensated by an increase in mealtime insulin, after this period the regimen should be adjusted individually.

data.Element: Close metabolic monitoring is recommended during the switch and in the initial weeks thereafter.
data.Text: Close metabolic monitoring is recommended during the switch and in the initial weeks thereafter.

data.Element: With improved metabolic control and resulting increase in insulin sensitivity a further adjustment in dose regimen may become necessary. Dose adjustment may also be required, for example, if the patient's weight or life-style changes, change of timing of insulin dose or other circumstances arise that increase susceptibility to hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia (see section 4.4).
data.Text: With improved metabolic control and resulting increase in insulin sensitivity a further adjustment in dose regimen may become necessary. Dose adjustment may also be required, for example, if the patient's weight or life-style changes, change of timing of insulin dose or other circumstances arise that increase susceptibility to hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia (see section 4.4).

data.Element: Patients with high insulin doses because of antibodies to human insulin may experience an improved insulin response with ABASAGLAR.
data.Text: Patients with high insulin doses because of antibodies to human insulin may experience an improved insulin response with ABASAGLAR.
Method of administration
ABASAGLAR is administered subcutaneously.

data.Element: ABASAGLAR should not be administered intravenously. The prolonged duration of action of insulin glargine is dependent on its injection into subcutaneous tissue. Intravenous administration of the usual subcutaneous dose could result in severe hypoglycaemia.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR should not be administered intravenously. The prolonged duration of action of insulin glargine is dependent on its injection into subcutaneous tissue. Intravenous administration of the usual subcutaneous dose could result in severe hypoglycaemia.

data.Element: There are no clinically relevant differences in serum insulin or glucose levels after abdominal, deltoid or thigh administration of insulin glargine.
data.Text: There are no clinically relevant differences in serum insulin or glucose levels after abdominal, deltoid or thigh administration of insulin glargine.

data.Element: Injection sites should always be rotated within the same region in order to reduce the risk of lipodystrophy and cutaneous amyloidosis (see section 4.4 and 4.8).
data.Text: Injection sites should always be rotated within the same region in order to reduce the risk of lipodystrophy and cutaneous amyloidosis (see section 4.4 and 4.8).

data.Element: ABASAGLAR must not be mixed with any other insulin or diluted. Mixing or diluting can change its time/action profile and mixing can cause precipitation.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR must not be mixed with any other insulin or diluted. Mixing or diluting can change its time/action profile and mixing can cause precipitation.

data.Element: For further details on handling, see section 6.6.
data.Text: For further details on handling, see section 6.6.

data.Element: Before using ABASAGLAR solution for injection in pre‑filled pen, the instructions for use included in the package leaflet must be read carefully (see section 6.6).
data.Text: Before using ABASAGLAR solution for injection in pre‑filled pen, the instructions for use included in the package leaflet must be read carefully (see section 6.6).
KwikPen

data.Element: The KwikPen is registered in two presentations. One delivers 1 –60 units in steps of 1 unit in a single injection and the other delivers 1 – 80 units in steps of 1 unit in a single injection. The needed dose is dialled in units. The number of units is shown in the dose window of the pen.
data.Text: The KwikPen is registered in two presentations. One delivers 1 –60 units in steps of 1 unit in a single injection and the other delivers 1 – 80 units in steps of 1 unit in a single injection. The needed dose is dialled in units. The number of units is shown in the dose window of the pen.
Tempo Pen

data.Element: The Tempo Pen delivers 1 – 80 units in steps of 1 unit in a single injection. The needed dose is dialled in units. The number of units is shown in the dose window of the pen.
data.Text: The Tempo Pen delivers 1 – 80 units in steps of 1 unit in a single injection. The needed dose is dialled in units. The number of units is shown in the dose window of the pen.

data.Element: The Tempo Pen can be used with the optional transfer module Tempo Smart Button (see section 6.6).
data.Text: The Tempo Pen can be used with the optional transfer module Tempo Smart Button (see section 6.6).

data.Element: As with any insulin injection, when using the Tempo Pen, Smart Button and the mobile application, the patient should be instructed to check their blood sugar levels when considering or making decisions about another injection if they are unsure how much they have injected.
data.Text: As with any insulin injection, when using the Tempo Pen, Smart Button and the mobile application, the patient should be instructed to check their blood sugar levels when considering or making decisions about another injection if they are unsure how much they have injected.
4.3     Contraindications

data.Element: Hypersensitivity to the active substance or to any of the excipients listed in section 6.1.
data.Text: Hypersensitivity to the active substance or to any of the excipients listed in section 6.1.

data.Element: 4.4 Special warnings and precautions for use
data.Text: 4.4     Special warnings and precautions for use
Traceability

data.Element: In order to improve the traceability of biological medicinal products, the name and the batch number of the administered medicinal product should be clearly recorded.
data.Text: In order to improve the traceability of biological medicinal products, the name and the batch number of the administered medicinal product should be clearly recorded.
Diabetic ketoacidosis

data.Element: ABASAGLAR is not the insulin of choice for the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis. Instead, regular insulin administered intravenously is recommended in such cases.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR is not the insulin of choice for the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis. Instead, regular insulin administered intravenously is recommended in such cases.

data.Element: Insulin requirements and dose adjustments
data.Text: Insulin requirements and dose adjustments

data.Element: In case of insufficient glucose control or a tendency to hyperglycaemic or hypoglycaemic episodes, the patient's adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen, injection sites and proper injection technique and all other relevant factors must be reviewed before dose adjustment is considered.
data.Text: In case of insufficient glucose control or a tendency to hyperglycaemic or hypoglycaemic episodes, the patient's adherence to the prescribed treatment regimen, injection sites and proper injection technique and all other relevant factors must be reviewed before dose adjustment is considered.

data.Element: Transferring a patient to another type or brand of insulin should be done under strict medical supervision. Changes in strength, brand (manufacturer), type (regular, NPH, lente, long‑acting, etc.), origin (animal, human, human insulin analogue) and/or method of manufacture may result in the need for a change in dose.
data.Text: Transferring a patient to another type or brand of insulin should be done under strict medical supervision. Changes in strength, brand (manufacturer), type (regular, NPH, lente, long‑acting, etc.), origin (animal, human, human insulin analogue) and/or method of manufacture may result in the need for a change in dose.
Hypoglycaemia

data.Element: The time of occurrence of hypoglycaemia depends on the action profile of the insulins used and may, therefore, change when the treatment regimen is changed. Due to more sustained basal insulin supply with insulin glargine, less nocturnal but more early morning hypoglycaemia can be expected.
data.Text: The time of occurrence of hypoglycaemia depends on the action profile of the insulins used and may, therefore, change when the treatment regimen is changed. Due to more sustained basal insulin supply with insulin glargine, less nocturnal but more early morning hypoglycaemia can be expected.

data.Element: Particular caution should be exercised, and intensified blood glucose monitoring is advisable in patients in whom hypoglycaemic episodes might be of particular clinical relevance, such as in patients with significant stenoses of the coronary arteries or of the blood vessels supplying the brain (risk of cardiac or cerebral complications of hypoglycaemia) as well as in patients with proliferative retinopathy, particularly if not treated with photocoagulation (risk of transient amaurosis following hypoglycaemia).
data.Text: Particular caution should be exercised, and intensified blood glucose monitoring is advisable in patients in whom hypoglycaemic episodes might be of particular clinical relevance, such as in patients with significant stenoses of the coronary arteries or of the blood vessels supplying the brain (risk of cardiac or cerebral complications of hypoglycaemia) as well as in patients with proliferative retinopathy, particularly if not treated with photocoagulation (risk of transient amaurosis following hypoglycaemia).

data.Element: Patients should be aware of circumstances where warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia are diminished. The warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia may be changed, be less pronounced or be absent in certain risk groups. These include patients:
data.Text: Patients should be aware of circumstances where warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia are diminished. The warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia may be changed, be less pronounced or be absent in certain risk groups. These include patients:

data.Element: - in whom glycaemic control is markedly improved,
data.Text: -        in whom glycaemic control is markedly improved,

data.Element: - in whom hypoglycaemia develops gradually,
data.Text: -        in whom hypoglycaemia develops gradually,

data.Element: - who are elderly,
data.Text: -        who are elderly,

data.Element: - after transfer from animal insulin to human insulin,
data.Text: -        after transfer from animal insulin to human insulin,

data.Element: - in whom an autonomic neuropathy is present,
data.Text: -        in whom an autonomic neuropathy is present,

data.Element: - with a long history of diabetes,
data.Text: -        with a long history of diabetes,

data.Element: - suffering from a psychiatric illness,
data.Text: -        suffering from a psychiatric illness,

data.Element: - receiving concurrent treatment with certain other medicinal products (see section 4.5).
data.Text: -        receiving concurrent treatment with certain other medicinal products (see section 4.5).

data.Element: Such situations may result in severe hypoglycaemia (and possibly loss of consciousness) prior to the patient's awareness of hypoglycaemia.
data.Text: Such situations may result in severe hypoglycaemia (and possibly loss of consciousness) prior to the patient's awareness of hypoglycaemia.

data.Element: The prolonged effect of subcutaneous insulin glargine may delay recovery from hypoglycaemia.
data.Text: The prolonged effect of subcutaneous insulin glargine may delay recovery from hypoglycaemia.

data.Element: If normal or decreased values for glycated haemoglobin are noted, the possibility of recurrent, unrecognised (especially nocturnal) episodes of hypoglycaemia must be considered.
data.Text: If normal or decreased values for glycated haemoglobin are noted, the possibility of recurrent, unrecognised (especially nocturnal) episodes of hypoglycaemia must be considered.

data.Element: Adherence of the patient to the dose and dietary regimen, correct insulin administration and awareness of hypoglycaemia symptoms are essential to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia. Factors increasing the susceptibility to hypoglycaemia require particularly close monitoring and may necessitate dose adjustment. These include:
data.Text: Adherence of the patient to the dose and dietary regimen, correct insulin administration and awareness of hypoglycaemia symptoms are essential to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia. Factors increasing the susceptibility to hypoglycaemia require particularly close monitoring and may necessitate dose adjustment. These include:

data.Element: - change in the injection area,
data.Text: -        change in the injection area,

data.Element: - improved insulin sensitivity (e.g., by removal of stress factors),
data.Text: -        improved insulin sensitivity (e.g., by removal of stress factors),

data.Element: - unaccustomed, increased or prolonged physical activity,
data.Text: -        unaccustomed, increased or prolonged physical activity,

data.Element: - intercurrent illness (e.g. vomiting, diarrhoea),
data.Text: -        intercurrent illness (e.g. vomiting, diarrhoea),

data.Element: - inadequate food intake,
data.Text: -        inadequate food intake,
-        missed meals,
-        alcohol consumption,

data.Element: - certain uncompensated endocrine disorders, (e.g. in hypothyroidism and in anterior pituitary or adrenocortical insufficiency),
data.Text: -        certain uncompensated endocrine disorders, (e.g. in hypothyroidism and in anterior pituitary or adrenocortical insufficiency),

data.Element: - concomitant treatment with certain other medicinal products.
data.Text: -        concomitant treatment with certain other medicinal products.
Injection technique

data.Element: Patients must be instructed to perform continuous rotation of the injection site to reduce the risk of developing lipodystrophy and cutaneous amyloidosis. There is a potential risk of delayed insulin absorption and worsened glycaemic control following insulin injections at sites with these reactions. A sudden change in the injection site to an unaffected area has been reported to result in hypoglycaemia. Blood glucose monitoring is recommended after the change in the injection site, and dose adjustment of antidiabetic medications may be considered.
data.Text: Patients must be instructed to perform continuous rotation of the injection site to reduce the risk of developing lipodystrophy and cutaneous amyloidosis. There is a potential risk of delayed insulin absorption and worsened glycaemic control following insulin injections at sites with these reactions. A sudden change in the injection site to an unaffected area has been reported to result in hypoglycaemia. Blood glucose monitoring is recommended after the change in the injection site, and dose adjustment of antidiabetic medications may be considered.
Intercurrent illness

data.Element: Intercurrent illness requires intensified metabolic monitoring. In many cases urine tests for ketones are indicated, and often it is necessary to adjust the insulin dose. The insulin requirement is often increased. Patients with type 1 diabetes must continue to consume at least a small amount of carbohydrates on a regular basis, even if they are able to eat only little or no food, or are vomiting etc. and they must never omit insulin entirely.
data.Text: Intercurrent illness requires intensified metabolic monitoring. In many cases urine tests for ketones are indicated, and often it is necessary to adjust the insulin dose. The insulin requirement is often increased. Patients with type 1 diabetes must continue to consume at least a small amount of carbohydrates on a regular basis, even if they are able to eat only little or no food, or are vomiting etc. and they must never omit insulin entirely.
Insulin antibodies

data.Element: Insulin administration may cause insulin antibodies to form. In rare cases, the presence of such insulin antibodies may necessitate adjustment of the insulin dose in order to correct a tendency to hyper- or hypoglycaemia (see section 5.1).
data.Text: Insulin administration may cause insulin antibodies to form. In rare cases, the presence of such insulin antibodies may necessitate adjustment of the insulin dose in order to correct a tendency to hyper- or hypoglycaemia (see section 5.1).
Medication errors

data.Element: Medication errors have been reported in which other insulins, particularly short‑acting insulins, have been accidentally administered instead of insulin glargine. Insulin label must always be checked before each injection to avoid medication errors between ABASAGLAR pre-filled pen as well as other insulins.
data.Text: Medication errors have been reported in which other insulins, particularly short‑acting insulins, have been accidentally administered instead of insulin glargine. Insulin label must always be checked before each injection to avoid medication errors between ABASAGLAR pre-filled pen as well as other insulins.

data.Element: Combination of ABASAGLAR with pioglitazone
data.Text: Combination of ABASAGLAR with pioglitazone

data.Element: Cases of cardiac failure have been reported when pioglitazone was used in combination with insulin, especially in patients with risk factors for development of cardiac heart failure. This should be kept in mind if treatment with the combination of pioglitazone and ABASAGLAR is considered. If the combination is used, patients should be observed for signs and symptoms of heart failure, weight gain and oedema. Pioglitazone should be discontinued if any deterioration in cardiac symptoms occurs.
data.Text: Cases of cardiac failure have been reported when pioglitazone was used in combination with insulin, especially in patients with risk factors for development of cardiac heart failure. This should be kept in mind if treatment with the combination of pioglitazone and ABASAGLAR is considered. If the combination is used, patients should be observed for signs and symptoms of heart failure, weight gain and oedema. Pioglitazone should be discontinued if any deterioration in cardiac symptoms occurs.
Tempo Pen

data.Element: The Tempo Pen contains a magnet (see section 6.5) that may interfere with the functions of an implantable electronic medical device, such as a pacemaker. The magnetic field extends to approximately 1.5 cm.
data.Text: The Tempo Pen contains a magnet (see section 6.5) that may interfere with the functions of an implantable electronic medical device, such as a pacemaker. The magnetic field extends to approximately 1.5 cm.
Sodium content

data.Element: This medicinal product contains less than 1 mmol sodium (23 mg) per dose, i.e., essentially “sodium‑free”.
data.Text: This medicinal product contains less than 1 mmol sodium (23 mg) per dose, i.e., essentially “sodium‑free”.

data.Element: 4.5 Interaction with other medicinal products and other forms of interaction
data.Text: 4.5     Interaction with other medicinal products and other forms of interaction

data.Element: A number of substances affect glucose metabolism and may require dose adjustment of insulin glargine.
data.Text: A number of substances affect glucose metabolism and may require dose adjustment of insulin glargine.

data.Element: Substances that may enhance the blood-glucose‑lowering effect and increase susceptibility to hypoglycaemia include oral antidiabetic medicinal products, angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, disopyramide, fibrates, fluoxetine, monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors, pentoxifylline, propoxyphene, salicylates, somatostatin anologues and sulphonamide antibiotics.
data.Text: Substances that may enhance the blood-glucose‑lowering effect and increase susceptibility to hypoglycaemia include oral antidiabetic medicinal products, angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, disopyramide, fibrates, fluoxetine, monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors, pentoxifylline, propoxyphene, salicylates, somatostatin anologues and sulphonamide antibiotics.

data.Element: Substances that may reduce the blood-glucose-lowering effect include corticosteroids, danazol, diazoxide, diuretics, glucagon, isoniazid, oestrogens, progestogens, phenothiazine derivatives, somatropin, sympathomimetic medicinal products (e.g. epinephrine [adrenaline], salbutamol, terbutaline), thyroid hormones, atypical antipsychotic medicinal products (e.g. clozapine and olanzapine) and protease inhibitors.
data.Text: Substances that may reduce the blood-glucose-lowering effect include corticosteroids, danazol, diazoxide, diuretics, glucagon, isoniazid, oestrogens, progestogens, phenothiazine derivatives, somatropin, sympathomimetic medicinal products (e.g. epinephrine [adrenaline], salbutamol, terbutaline), thyroid hormones, atypical antipsychotic medicinal products (e.g. clozapine and olanzapine) and protease inhibitors.

data.Element: Beta-blockers, clonidine, lithium salts or alcohol may either potentiate or weaken the blood-glucose lowering effect of insulin. Pentamidine may cause hypoglycaemia, which may sometimes be followed by hyperglycaemia.
data.Text: Beta-blockers, clonidine, lithium salts or alcohol may either potentiate or weaken the blood-glucose lowering effect of insulin. Pentamidine may cause hypoglycaemia, which may sometimes be followed by hyperglycaemia.

data.Element: In addition, under the influence of sympatholytic medicinal products such as beta-blockers, clonidine, guanethidine and reserpine, the signs of adrenergic counter-regulation may be reduced or absent.
data.Text: In addition, under the influence of sympatholytic medicinal products such as beta-blockers, clonidine, guanethidine and reserpine, the signs of adrenergic counter-regulation may be reduced or absent.

data.Element: 4.6 Fertility, pregnancy and lactation
data.Text: 4.6     Fertility, pregnancy and lactation
Pregnancy

data.Element: For insulin glargine no clinical data on exposed pregnancies from controlled clinical studies are available. A large amount of data on pregnant women (more than 1,000 pregnancy outcomes) indicate no specific adverse effects of insulin glargine on pregnancy and no specific malformative nor feto/neonatal toxicity of insulin glargine.
data.Text: For insulin glargine no clinical data on exposed pregnancies from controlled clinical studies are available. A large amount of data on pregnant women (more than 1,000 pregnancy outcomes) indicate no specific adverse effects of insulin glargine on pregnancy and no specific malformative nor feto/neonatal toxicity of insulin glargine.

data.Element: Animal data do not indicate reproductive toxicity.
data.Text: Animal data do not indicate reproductive toxicity.

data.Element: The use of ABASAGLAR may be considered during pregnancy, if clinically needed.
data.Text: The use of ABASAGLAR may be considered during pregnancy, if clinically needed.

data.Element: It is essential for patients with pre-existing or gestational diabetes to maintain good metabolic control throughout pregnancy to prevent adverse outcomes associated with hyperglycaemia. Insulin requirements may decrease during the first trimester and generally increase during the second and third trimesters. Immediately after delivery, insulin requirements decline rapidly (increased risk of hypoglycaemia). Careful monitoring of glucose control is essential.
data.Text: It is essential for patients with pre-existing or gestational diabetes to maintain good metabolic control throughout pregnancy to prevent adverse outcomes associated with hyperglycaemia. Insulin requirements may decrease during the first trimester and generally increase during the second and third trimesters. Immediately after delivery, insulin requirements decline rapidly (increased risk of hypoglycaemia). Careful monitoring of glucose control is essential.
Breast-feeding

data.Element: It is unknown whether insulin glargine is excreted in human milk. No metabolic effects of ingested insulin glargine on the breast‑fed newborn/infant are anticipated since insulin glargine as a peptide is digested into amino acids in the human gastrointestinal tract.
data.Text: It is unknown whether insulin glargine is excreted in human milk. No metabolic effects of ingested insulin glargine on the breast‑fed newborn/infant are anticipated since insulin glargine as a peptide is digested into amino acids in the human gastrointestinal tract.

data.Element: Breast-feeding women may require adjustments in insulin dose and diet.
data.Text: Breast-feeding women may require adjustments in insulin dose and diet.
Fertility

data.Element: Animal studies do not indicate direct harmful effects with respect to fertility.
data.Text: Animal studies do not indicate direct harmful effects with respect to fertility.

data.Element: 4.7 Effects on ability to drive and use machines
data.Text: 4.7     Effects on ability to drive and use machines

data.Element: The patient's ability to concentrate and react may be impaired as a result of hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia or, for example, as a result of visual impairment. This may constitute a risk in situations where these abilities are of special importance (e.g. driving a car or using machines).
data.Text: The patient's ability to concentrate and react may be impaired as a result of hypoglycaemia or hyperglycaemia or, for example, as a result of visual impairment. This may constitute a risk in situations where these abilities are of special importance (e.g. driving a car or using machines).

data.Element: Patients should be advised to take precautions to avoid hypoglycaemia whilst driving. This is particularly important in those who have reduced or absent awareness of the warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia or have frequent episodes of hypoglycaemia. It should be considered whether it is advisable to drive or operate machines in these circumstances.
data.Text: Patients should be advised to take precautions to avoid hypoglycaemia whilst driving. This is particularly important in those who have reduced or absent awareness of the warning symptoms of hypoglycaemia or have frequent episodes of hypoglycaemia. It should be considered whether it is advisable to drive or operate machines in these circumstances.
4.8     Undesirable effects
Summary of safety profile

data.Element: Hypoglycaemia (very common), in general the most frequent adverse reaction of insulin therapy, may occur if the insulin dose is too high in relation to the insulin requirement (see section 4.4).
data.Text: Hypoglycaemia (very common), in general the most frequent adverse reaction of insulin therapy, may occur if the insulin dose is too high in relation to the insulin requirement (see section 4.4).

data.Element: Description of selected adverse reactions
data.Text: Description of selected adverse reactions
Metabolism and nutrition disorders

data.Element: Severe hypoglycaemic attacks, especially if recurrent, may lead to neurological damage. Prolonged or severe hypoglycaemic episodes may be life-threatening. In many patients, the signs and symptoms of neuroglycopenia are preceded by signs of adrenergic counter-regulation. Generally, the greater and more rapid the decline in blood glucose, the more marked is the phenomenon of counter-regulation and its symptoms.
data.Text: Severe hypoglycaemic attacks, especially if recurrent, may lead to neurological damage. Prolonged or severe hypoglycaemic episodes may be life-threatening. In many patients, the signs and symptoms of neuroglycopenia are preceded by signs of adrenergic counter-regulation. Generally, the greater and more rapid the decline in blood glucose, the more marked is the phenomenon of counter-regulation and its symptoms.
Immune system disorders

data.Element: Immediate-type allergic reactions to insulin are rare. Such reactions to insulin (including insulin glargine) or the excipients may, for example, be associated with generalised skin reactions, angio-oedema, bronchospasm, hypotension and shock, and may be life-threatening.
data.Text: Immediate-type allergic reactions to insulin are rare. Such reactions to insulin (including insulin glargine) or the excipients may, for example, be associated with generalised skin reactions, angio-oedema, bronchospasm, hypotension and shock, and may be life-threatening.
Eyes disorders

data.Element: A marked change in glycaemic control may cause temporary visual impairment, due to temporary alteration in the turgidity and refractive index of the lens.
data.Text: A marked change in glycaemic control may cause temporary visual impairment, due to temporary alteration in the turgidity and refractive index of the lens.

data.Element: Long-term improved glycaemic control decreases the risk of progression of diabetic retinopathy. However, intensification of insulin therapy with abrupt improvement in glycaemic control may be associated with temporary worsening of diabetic retinopathy. In patients with proliferative retinopathy, particularly if not treated with photocoagulation, severe hypoglycaemic episodes may result in transient amaurosis.
data.Text: Long-term improved glycaemic control decreases the risk of progression of diabetic retinopathy. However, intensification of insulin therapy with abrupt improvement in glycaemic control may be associated with temporary worsening of diabetic retinopathy. In patients with proliferative retinopathy, particularly if not treated with photocoagulation, severe hypoglycaemic episodes may result in transient amaurosis.

data.Element: Skin and subcutaneous tissue disorders
data.Text: Skin and subcutaneous tissue disorders

data.Element: Lipodystrophy and cutaneous amyloidosis may occur at the injection site and delay local insulin absorption. Continuous rotation of the injection site within the given injection area may help to reduce or prevent these reactions (see section 4.4).
data.Text: Lipodystrophy and cutaneous amyloidosis may occur at the injection site and delay local insulin absorption. Continuous rotation of the injection site within the given injection area may help to reduce or prevent these reactions (see section 4.4).

data.Element: General disorders and administration site conditions
data.Text: General disorders and administration site conditions

data.Element: Injection site reactions include redness, pain, itching, hives, swelling, or inflammation. Most minor reactions to insulins at the injection site usually resolve in a few days to a few weeks.
data.Text: Injection site reactions include redness, pain, itching, hives, swelling, or inflammation. Most minor reactions to insulins at the injection site usually resolve in a few days to a few weeks.

data.Element: Rarely, insulin may cause sodium retention and oedema particularly if previously poor metabolic control is improved by intensified insulin therapy.
data.Text: Rarely, insulin may cause sodium retention and oedema particularly if previously poor metabolic control is improved by intensified insulin therapy.
Paediatric population

data.Element: In general, the safety profile for children and adolescents (≤ 18 years of age) is similar to the safety profile for adults. The adverse reaction reports received from post marketing surveillance included relatively more frequent injection site reactions (injection site pain, injection site reaction) and skin reactions (rash, urticaria) in children and adolescents (≤ 18 years of age) than in adults. Clinical study safety data are not available for children under 2 years.
data.Text: In general, the safety profile for children and adolescents (≤ 18 years of age) is similar to the safety profile for adults. The adverse reaction reports received from post marketing surveillance included relatively more frequent injection site reactions (injection site pain, injection site reaction) and skin reactions (rash, urticaria) in children and adolescents (≤ 18 years of age) than in adults. Clinical study safety data are not available for children under 2 years.

data.Element: Reporting of suspected adverse reactions
data.Text: Reporting of suspected adverse reactions

data.Element: Reporting suspected adverse reactions after authorisation of the medicinal product is important. It allows continued monitoring of the benefit/risk balance of the medicinal product. Healthcare professionals are asked to report any suspected adverse reactions via the national reporting system listed in Appendix V.
data.Text: Reporting suspected adverse reactions after authorisation of the medicinal product is important. It allows continued monitoring of the benefit/risk balance of the medicinal product. Healthcare professionals are asked to report any suspected adverse reactions via the national reporting system listed in Appendix V.
4.9     Overdose
Symptoms

data.Element: Insulin overdose may lead to severe and sometimes long-term and life-threatening hypoglycaemia.
data.Text: Insulin overdose may lead to severe and sometimes long-term and life-threatening hypoglycaemia.
Management

data.Element: Mild episodes of hypoglycaemia can usually be treated with oral carbohydrates. Adjustments in dose of the medicinal product, meal patterns, or physical activity may be needed.
data.Text: Mild episodes of hypoglycaemia can usually be treated with oral carbohydrates. Adjustments in dose of the medicinal product, meal patterns, or physical activity may be needed.

data.Element: More severe episodes with coma, seizure, or neurologic impairment may be treated with intramuscular/subcutaneous glucagon or concentrated intravenous glucose. Sustained carbohydrate intake and observation may be necessary because hypoglycaemia may recur after apparent clinical recovery.
data.Text: More severe episodes with coma, seizure, or neurologic impairment may be treated with intramuscular/subcutaneous glucagon or concentrated intravenous glucose. Sustained carbohydrate intake and observation may be necessary because hypoglycaemia may recur after apparent clinical recovery.
5.       PHARMACOLOGICAL PROPERTIES
5.1     Pharmacodynamic properties

data.Element: Pharmacotherapeutic group: Drugs used in diabetes, insulins and analogues for injection, long-acting. ATC Code: A10AE04.
data.Text: Pharmacotherapeutic group: Drugs used in diabetes, insulins and analogues for injection, long-acting. ATC Code: A10AE04.

data.Element: ABASAGLAR is a biosimilar medicinal product. Detailed information is available on the website of the European Medicines Agency http://www.ema.europa.eu.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR is a biosimilar medicinal product. Detailed information is available on the website of the European Medicines Agency http://www.ema.europa.eu.
Mechanism of action

data.Element: Insulin glargine is a human insulin analogue designed to have a low solubility at neutral pH. It is completely soluble at the acidic pH of the ABASAGLAR injection solution (pH 4). After injection into the subcutaneous tissue, the acidic solution is neutralised leading to formation of micro-precipitates from which small amounts of insulin glargine are continuously released, providing a smooth, peakless, predictable concentration/time profile with a prolonged duration of action.
data.Text: Insulin glargine is a human insulin analogue designed to have a low solubility at neutral pH. It is completely soluble at the acidic pH of the ABASAGLAR injection solution (pH 4). After injection into the subcutaneous tissue, the acidic solution is neutralised leading to formation of micro-precipitates from which small amounts of insulin glargine are continuously released, providing a smooth, peakless, predictable concentration/time profile with a prolonged duration of action.

data.Element: Insulin glargine is metabolised into 2 active metabolites M1 and M2 (see section 5.2).
data.Text: Insulin glargine is metabolised into 2 active metabolites M1 and M2 (see section 5.2).
Insulin receptor binding

data.Element: In vitro studies indicate that the affinity of insulin glargine and its metabolites M1 and M2 for the human insulin receptor is similar to the one of human insulin.
data.Text: In vitro studies indicate that the affinity of insulin glargine and its metabolites M1 and M2 for the human insulin receptor is similar to the one of human insulin.

data.Element: IGF-1 receptor binding: The affinity of insulin glargine for the human IGF-1 receptor is approximately 5 to 8-fold greater than that of human insulin (but approximately 70 to 80-fold lower than the one of IGF-1), whereas M1 and M2 bind the IGF-1 receptor with slightly lower affinity compared to human insulin.
data.Text: IGF-1 receptor binding: The affinity of insulin glargine for the human IGF-1 receptor is approximately 5 to 8-fold greater than that of human insulin (but approximately 70 to 80-fold lower than the one of IGF-1), whereas M1 and M2 bind the IGF-1 receptor with slightly lower affinity compared to human insulin.

data.Element: The total therapeutic insulin concentration (insulin glargine and its metabolites) found in type 1 diabetic patients was markedly lower than what would be required for a half maximal occupation of the IGF-1 receptor and the subsequent activation of the mitogenic-proliferative pathway initiated by the IGF-1 receptor. Physiological concentrations of endogenous IGF-1 may activate the mitogenic-proliferative pathway; however, the therapeutic concentrations found in insulin therapy, including in ABASAGLAR therapy, are considerably lower than the pharmacological concentrations required to activate the IGF-1 pathway.
data.Text: The total therapeutic insulin concentration (insulin glargine and its metabolites) found in type 1 diabetic patients was markedly lower than what would be required for a half maximal occupation of the IGF-1 receptor and the subsequent activation of the mitogenic-proliferative pathway initiated by the IGF-1 receptor. Physiological concentrations of endogenous IGF-1 may activate the mitogenic-proliferative pathway; however, the therapeutic concentrations found in insulin therapy, including in ABASAGLAR therapy, are considerably lower than the pharmacological concentrations required to activate the IGF-1 pathway.
Pharmacodynamic effects

data.Element: The primary activity of insulin, including insulin glargine, is regulation of glucose metabolism. Insulin and its analogues lower blood glucose levels by stimulating peripheral glucose uptake, especially by skeletal muscle and fat, and by inhibiting hepatic glucose production. Insulin inhibits lipolysis in the adipocyte, inhibits proteolysis and enhances protein synthesis.
data.Text: The primary activity of insulin, including insulin glargine, is regulation of glucose metabolism. Insulin and its analogues lower blood glucose levels by stimulating peripheral glucose uptake, especially by skeletal muscle and fat, and by inhibiting hepatic glucose production. Insulin inhibits lipolysis in the adipocyte, inhibits proteolysis and enhances protein synthesis.

data.Element: In clinical pharmacology studies, intravenous insulin glargine and human insulin have been shown to be equipotent when given at the same doses. As with all insulins, the time course of action of insulin glargine may be affected by physical activity and other variables.
data.Text: In clinical pharmacology studies, intravenous insulin glargine and human insulin have been shown to be equipotent when given at the same doses. As with all insulins, the time course of action of insulin glargine may be affected by physical activity and other variables.

data.Element: In euglycaemic clamp studies in healthy subjects or in patients with type 1 diabetes, the onset of action of subcutaneous insulin glargine was slower than with human NPH insulin, its effect profile was smooth and peakless, and the duration of its effect was prolonged.
data.Text: In euglycaemic clamp studies in healthy subjects or in patients with type 1 diabetes, the onset of action of subcutaneous insulin glargine was slower than with human NPH insulin, its effect profile was smooth and peakless, and the duration of its effect was prolonged.

data.Text: Figure 1: Activity profile in patients with type 1 diabetes

data.Element: * Determined as amount of glucose infused to maintain constant plasma glucose levels (hourly mean values)
data.Text: * Determined as amount of glucose infused to maintain constant plasma glucose levels (hourly mean values)

data.Element: The longer duration of action of subcutaneous insulin glargine is directly related to its slower rate of absorption and supports once daily administration. The time course of action of insulin and insulin analogues such as insulin glargine may vary considerably in different individuals or within the same individual
data.Text: The longer duration of action of subcutaneous insulin glargine is directly related to its slower rate of absorption and supports once daily administration. The time course of action of insulin and insulin analogues such as insulin glargine may vary considerably in different individuals or within the same individual

data.Element: In a clinical study, symptoms of hypoglycaemia or counter-regulatory hormone responses were similar after intravenous insulin glargine and human insulin both in healthy volunteers and patients with type 1 diabetes.
data.Text: In a clinical study, symptoms of hypoglycaemia or counter-regulatory hormone responses were similar after intravenous insulin glargine and human insulin both in healthy volunteers and patients with type 1 diabetes.
Clinical safety and efficacy

data.Element: In clinical studies, antibodies that cross-react with human insulin and insulin glargine were observed with the same frequency in both NPH-insulin and insulin glargine treatment groups.
data.Text: In clinical studies, antibodies that cross-react with human insulin and insulin glargine were observed with the same frequency in both NPH-insulin and insulin glargine treatment groups.

data.Element: Effects of insulin glargine (once daily) on diabetic retinopathy were evaluated in an open-label 5 year NPH-controlled study (NPH given bid) in 1024 type 2 diabetic patients in which progression of retinopathy by 3 or more steps on the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) scale was investigated by fundus photography. No significant difference was seen in the progression of diabetic retinopathy when insulin glargine was compared to NPH insulin.
data.Text: Effects of insulin glargine (once daily) on diabetic retinopathy were evaluated in an open-label 5 year NPH-controlled study (NPH given bid) in 1024 type 2 diabetic patients in which progression of retinopathy by 3 or more steps on the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) scale was investigated by fundus photography. No significant difference was seen in the progression of diabetic retinopathy when insulin glargine was compared to NPH insulin.

data.Element: The ORIGIN (Outcome Reduction with Initial Glargine INtervention) study was a multicenter, randomised, 2x2 factorial design study conducted in 12,537 participants at high cardiovascular (CV) risk with impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) (12% of participants) or type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with ≤1 antidiabetic oral agent (88% of participants). Participants were randomised (1:1) to receive insulin glargine (n=6,264), titrated to reach FPG ≤95 mg/dL (5.3 mM), or standard care (n=6,273).
data.Text: The ORIGIN (Outcome Reduction with Initial Glargine INtervention) study was a multicenter, randomised, 2x2 factorial design study conducted in 12,537 participants at high cardiovascular (CV) risk with impaired fasting glucose (IFG) or impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) (12% of participants) or type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with ≤1 antidiabetic oral agent (88% of participants). Participants were randomised (1:1) to receive insulin glargine (n=6,264), titrated to reach FPG ≤95 mg/dL (5.3 mM), or standard care (n=6,273).

data.Element: The first co-primary efficacy outcome was the time to the first occurrence of CV death, nonfatal myocardial infarction (MI), or nonfatal stroke, and the second co-primary efficacy outcome was the time to the first occurrence of any of the first co-primary events, or revascularisation procedure (coronary, carotid, or peripheral), or hospitalisation for heart failure.
data.Text: The first co-primary efficacy outcome was the time to the first occurrence of CV death, nonfatal myocardial infarction (MI), or nonfatal stroke, and the second co-primary efficacy outcome was the time to the first occurrence of any of the first co-primary events, or revascularisation procedure (coronary, carotid, or peripheral), or hospitalisation for heart failure.

data.Element: Secondary endpoints included all-cause mortality and a composite microvascular outcome.
data.Text: Secondary endpoints included all-cause mortality and a composite microvascular outcome.

data.Element: Insulin glargine did not alter the relative risk for CV disease and CV mortality when compared to standard of care. There were no differences between insulin glargine and standard care for the two co-primary outcomes; for any component endpoint comprising these outcomes; for all-cause mortality; or for the composite microvascular outcome.
data.Text: Insulin glargine did not alter the relative risk for CV disease and CV mortality when compared to standard of care. There were no differences between insulin glargine and standard care for the two co-primary outcomes; for any component endpoint comprising these outcomes; for all-cause mortality; or for the composite microvascular outcome.

data.Element: Mean dose of insulin glargine by study end was 0.42 U/kg. At baseline, participants had a median HbA1c value of 6.4% and median on-treatment HbA1c values ranged from 5.9 to 6.4% in the insulin glargine group, and 6.2% to 6.6% in the standard care group throughout the duration of follow-up. The rates of severe hypoglycaemia (affected participants per 100 participant years of exposure) were 1.05 for insulin glargine and 0.30 for standard care group and the rates of confirmed non-severe hypoglycaemia were 7.71 for insulin glargine and 2.44 for standard care group. Over the course of this 6-year study, 42% of the insulin glargine group did not experience any hypoglycaemia.
data.Text: Mean dose of insulin glargine by study end was 0.42 U/kg. At baseline, participants had a median HbA1c value of 6.4% and median on-treatment HbA1c values ranged from 5.9 to 6.4% in the insulin glargine group, and 6.2% to 6.6% in the standard care group throughout the duration of follow-up. The rates of severe hypoglycaemia (affected participants per 100 participant years of exposure) were 1.05 for insulin glargine and 0.30 for standard care group and the rates of confirmed non-severe hypoglycaemia were 7.71 for insulin glargine and 2.44 for standard care group. Over the course of this 6-year study, 42% of the insulin glargine group did not experience any hypoglycaemia.

data.Element: At the last on-treatment visit, there was a mean increase in body weight from baseline of 1.4 kg in the insulin glargine group and a mean decrease of 0.8 kg in the standard care group.
data.Text: At the last on-treatment visit, there was a mean increase in body weight from baseline of 1.4 kg in the insulin glargine group and a mean decrease of 0.8 kg in the standard care group.
Paediatric population

data.Element: In a randomised, controlled clinical study, paediatric patients (age range 6 to 15 years) with type 1 diabetes (n=349) were treated for 28 weeks with a basal-bolus insulin regimen where regular human insulin was used before each meal. Insulin glargine was administered once daily at bedtime and NPH human insulin was administered once or twice daily. Similar effects on glycohaemoglobin and the incidence of symptomatic hypoglycaemia were observed in both treatment groups, however fasting plasma glucose decreased more from baseline in the insulin glargine group than in the NPH group. There was less severe hypoglycaemia in the insulin glargine group as well. One hundred forty three of the patients treated with insulin glargine in this study continued treatment with insulin glargine in an uncontrolled extension study with mean duration of follow-up of 2 years. No new safety signals were seen during this extended treatment with insulin glargine.
data.Text: In a randomised, controlled clinical study, paediatric patients (age range 6 to 15 years) with type 1 diabetes (n=349) were treated for 28 weeks with a basal-bolus insulin regimen where regular human insulin was used before each meal. Insulin glargine was administered once daily at bedtime and NPH human insulin was administered once or twice daily. Similar effects on glycohaemoglobin and the incidence of symptomatic hypoglycaemia were observed in both treatment groups, however fasting plasma glucose decreased more from baseline in the insulin glargine group than in the NPH group. There was less severe hypoglycaemia in the insulin glargine group as well. One hundred forty three of the patients treated with insulin glargine in this study continued treatment with insulin glargine in an uncontrolled extension study with mean duration of follow-up of 2 years. No new safety signals were seen during this extended treatment with insulin glargine.

data.Element: A crossover study comparing insulin glargine plus lispro insulin to NPH plus regular human insulin (each treatment administered for 16 weeks in random order) in 26 adolescent type 1 diabetic patients aged 12 to 18 years was also performed. As in the paediatric study described above, fasting plasma glucose reduction from baseline was greater in the insulin glargine group than in the NPH group. HbA1c changes from baseline were similar between treatment groups; however blood glucose values recorded overnight were significantly higher in the insulin glargine/ lispro group than the NPH/regular group, with a mean nadir of 5.4 mM vs. 4.1 mM. Correspondingly, the incidences of nocturnal hypoglycaemia were 32 % in the insulin glargine / lispro group vs. 52 % in the NPH / regular group.
data.Text: A crossover study comparing insulin glargine plus lispro insulin to NPH plus regular human insulin (each treatment administered for 16 weeks in random order) in 26 adolescent type 1 diabetic patients aged 12 to 18 years was also performed. As in the paediatric study described above, fasting plasma glucose reduction from baseline was greater in the insulin glargine group than in the NPH group. HbA1c changes from baseline were similar between treatment groups; however blood glucose values recorded overnight were significantly higher in the insulin glargine/ lispro group than the NPH/regular group, with a mean nadir of 5.4 mM vs. 4.1 mM. Correspondingly, the incidences of nocturnal hypoglycaemia were 32 % in the insulin glargine / lispro group vs. 52 % in the NPH / regular group.

data.Element: A 24-week parallel group study was conducted in 125 children with type 1 diabetes mellitus aged 2 to 6 years, comparing insulin glargine given once daily in the morning to NPH insulin given once or twice daily as basal insulin. Both groups received bolus insulin before meals. The primary aim of demonstrating non-inferiority of insulin glargine to NPH in all hypoglycaemia was not met and there was a trend to an increase of hypoglycaemic events with insulin glargine [insulin glargine: NPH rate ratio (95% CI) = 1.18 (0.97-1.44)]. Glycohaemoglobin and glucose variabilities were comparable in both treatment groups. No new safety signals were observed in this trial.
data.Text: A 24-week parallel group study was conducted in 125 children with type 1 diabetes mellitus aged 2 to 6 years, comparing insulin glargine given once daily in the morning to NPH insulin given once or twice daily as basal insulin. Both groups received bolus insulin before meals. The primary aim of demonstrating non-inferiority of insulin glargine to NPH in all hypoglycaemia was not met and there was a trend to an increase of hypoglycaemic events with insulin glargine [insulin glargine: NPH rate ratio (95% CI) = 1.18 (0.97-1.44)]. Glycohaemoglobin and glucose variabilities were comparable in both treatment groups. No new safety signals were observed in this trial.
5.2     Pharmacokinetic properties
Absorption

data.Element: In healthy subjects and diabetic patients, insulin serum concentrations indicated a slower and much more prolonged absorption and showed a lack of a peak after subcutaneous injection of insulin glargine in comparison to human NPH insulin. Concentrations were thus consistent with the time profile of the pharmacodynamic activity of insulin glargine. Figure 1 above shows the activity profiles over time of insulin glargine and NPH insulin.
data.Text: In healthy subjects and diabetic patients, insulin serum concentrations indicated a slower and much more prolonged absorption and showed a lack of a peak after subcutaneous injection of insulin glargine in comparison to human NPH insulin. Concentrations were thus consistent with the time profile of the pharmacodynamic activity of insulin glargine. Figure 1 above shows the activity profiles over time of insulin glargine and NPH insulin.

data.Element: Insulin glargine injected once daily will reach steady state levels in 2-4 days after the first dose.
data.Text: Insulin glargine injected once daily will reach steady state levels in 2-4 days after the first dose.
Biotransformation

data.Element: After subcutaneous injection in diabetic patients, insulin glargine is rapidly metabolised at the carboxyl terminus of the Beta chain with formation of two active metabolites M1 (21A-Gly-insulin) and M2 (21A-Gly-des-30B-Thr-insulin). In plasma, the principal circulating compound is the metabolite M1. The exposure to M1 increases with the administered dose of insulin glargine.
data.Text: After subcutaneous injection in diabetic patients, insulin glargine is rapidly metabolised at the carboxyl terminus of the Beta chain with formation of two active metabolites M1 (21A-Gly-insulin) and M2 (21A-Gly-des-30B-Thr-insulin). In plasma, the principal circulating compound is the metabolite M1. The exposure to M1 increases with the administered dose of insulin glargine.

data.Element: The pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic findings indicate that the effect of the subcutaneous injection with insulin glargine is principally based on exposure to M1. Insulin glargine and the metabolite M2 were not detectable in the vast majority of subjects and, when they were detectable their concentration was independent of the administered dose of insulin glargine.
data.Text: The pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic findings indicate that the effect of the subcutaneous injection with insulin glargine is principally based on exposure to M1. Insulin glargine and the metabolite M2 were not detectable in the vast majority of subjects and, when they were detectable their concentration was independent of the administered dose of insulin glargine.
Elimination

data.Element: When given intravenously the elimination half-life of insulin glargine and human insulin were comparable.
data.Text: When given intravenously the elimination half-life of insulin glargine and human insulin were comparable.
Special populations

data.Element: In clinical studies, subgroup analyses based on age and gender did not indicate any difference in safety and efficacy in insulin glargine-treated patients compared to the entire study population.
data.Text: In clinical studies, subgroup analyses based on age and gender did not indicate any difference in safety and efficacy in insulin glargine-treated patients compared to the entire study population.
Paediatric population

data.Element: Pharmacokinetics in children aged 2 to less than 6 years with type 1 diabetes mellitus was assessed in one clinical study (see section 5.1). Plasma trough levels of insulin glargine and its main M1 and M2 metabolites were measured in children treated with insulin glargine, revealing plasma concentration patterns similar to adults, and providing no evidence for accumulation of insulin glargine or its metabolites with chronic dosing.
data.Text: Pharmacokinetics in children aged 2 to less than 6 years with type 1 diabetes mellitus was assessed in one clinical study (see section 5.1). Plasma trough levels of insulin glargine and its main M1 and M2 metabolites were measured in children treated with insulin glargine, revealing plasma concentration patterns similar to adults, and providing no evidence for accumulation of insulin glargine or its metabolites with chronic dosing.

data.Element: 6.6 Special precautions for disposal and other handling

data.Element: ABASAGLAR must not be mixed with any other insulin or medicinal products or diluted. Mixing or diluting can change its time/action profile and mixing can cause precipitation.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR must not be mixed with any other insulin or medicinal products or diluted. Mixing or diluting can change its time/action profile and mixing can cause precipitation.

data.Element: Inspect the cartridge before use. It must only be used if the solution is clear, colourless, with no solid particles visible, and if it is of water-like consistency. Since ABASAGLAR is a solution, it does not require re-suspension before use.
data.Text: Inspect the cartridge before use. It must only be used if the solution is clear, colourless, with no solid particles visible, and if it is of water-like consistency. Since ABASAGLAR is a solution, it does not require re-suspension before use.

data.Element: ABASAGLAR must not be mixed with any other insulin or diluted. Mixing or diluting can change its time/action profile and mixing can cause precipitation.

data.Element: Empty pens must never be reused and must be properly discarded.

data.Element: To prevent the possible transmission of disease, each pen must be used by one patient only.

data.Element: Insulin label must always be checked before each injection to avoid medication errors between insulin glargine and other insulins (see section 4.4).

Tempo Pen

data.Element: The Tempo Pen is designed to work with the Tempo Smart Button. The Tempo Smart Button is an optional product that can be attached to the Tempo Pen dose knob and aids in transmitting Abasaglar dose information from the Tempo Pen to a compatible mobile application. The Tempo Pen injects insulin with or without the Tempo Smart Button attached. To transmit data to the mobile application, follow the instructions provided with the Tempo Smart Button and the instructions with the mobile application.

data.Element: 1. What ABASAGLAR is and what it is used for
data.Text: 1.       What ABASAGLAR is and what it is used for

data.Element: ABASAGLAR contains insulin glargine. This is a modified insulin, very similar to human insulin.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR contains insulin glargine. This is a modified insulin, very similar to human insulin.

data.Element: ABASAGLAR is used to treat diabetes mellitus in adults, adolescents and children aged 2 years and above.
data.Text: ABASAGLAR is used to treat diabetes mellitus in adults, adolescents and children aged 2 years and above.

data.Element: Diabetes mellitus is a disease where your body does not produce enough insulin to control the level of blood sugar. Insulin glargine has a long and steady blood-sugar-lowering action.
data.Text: Diabetes mellitus is a disease where your body does not produce enough insulin to control the level of blood sugar. Insulin glargine has a long and steady blood-sugar-lowering action.

data.Element: 2. What you need to know before you use ABASAGLAR
data.Text: 2.       What you need to know before you use ABASAGLAR

data.Element: Do not use ABASAGLAR
data.Text: Do not use ABASAGLAR

data.Element: If you are allergic to insulin glargine or any of the other ingredients of this medicine (listed in section 6).
data.Text: If you are allergic to insulin glargine or any of the other ingredients of this medicine (listed in section 6).
Warnings and precautions

data.Element: Talk to your doctor, pharmacist or nurse before using ABASAGLAR.
data.Text: Talk to your doctor, pharmacist or nurse before using ABASAGLAR.

data.Element: Follow closely the instructions for posology, monitoring (blood and urine tests), diet and physical activity (physical work and exercise) as discussed with your doctor.
data.Text: Follow closely the instructions for posology, monitoring (blood and urine tests), diet and physical activity (physical work and exercise) as discussed with your doctor.

data.Element: If your blood sugar is too low (hypoglycaemia), follow the guidance for hypoglycaemia (see box at the end of this leaflet).
data.Text: If your blood sugar is too low (hypoglycaemia), follow the guidance for hypoglycaemia (see box at the end of this leaflet).

data.Element: Skin changes at the injection site.
data.Text: Skin changes at the injection site.

data.Element: The injection site should be rotated to prevent skin changes such as lumps under the skin. The insulin may not work well if you inject into a lumpy area (See How to use Abasaglar). Contact your doctor if you are currently injecting into a lumpy area before you start injecting into a different area. Your doctor may tell you to check your blood sugar more closely, and to adjust your insulin or your other antidiabetic medications dose.
data.Text: The injection site should be rotated to prevent skin changes such as lumps under the skin. The insulin may not work well if you inject into a lumpy area (See How to use Abasaglar). Contact your doctor if you are currently injecting into a lumpy area before you start injecting into a different area. Your doctor may tell you to check your blood sugar more closely, and to adjust your insulin or your other antidiabetic medications dose.
Travel

data.Element: Before travelling consult your doctor. You may need to talk about:
data.Text: Before travelling consult your doctor. You may need to talk about:

data.Element: - the availability of your insulin in the country you are visiting,
data.Text: -        the availability of your insulin in the country you are visiting,

data.Element: - supplies of insulin etc.
data.Text: -        supplies of insulin etc.

data.Element: - correct storage of your insulin while travelling,
data.Text: -        correct storage of your insulin while travelling,

data.Element: - timing of meals and insulin administration while travelling,
data.Text: -        timing of meals and insulin administration while travelling,

data.Element: - the possible effects of changing to different time zones,
data.Text: -        the possible effects of changing to different time zones,

data.Element: - possible new health risks in the countries to be visited,
data.Text: -        possible new health risks in the countries to be visited,

data.Element: - what you should do in emergency situations when you feel unwell or become ill.
data.Text: -        what you should do in emergency situations when you feel unwell or become ill.
Illnesses and injuries

data.Element: In the following situations, the management of your diabetes may require a lot of care (for example, adjustment to insulin dose, blood and urine tests):
data.Text: In the following situations, the management of your diabetes may require a lot of care (for example, adjustment to insulin dose, blood and urine tests):

data.Element: - If you are ill or have a major injury then your blood sugar level may increase (hyperglycaemia).
data.Text: -        If you are ill or have a major injury then your blood sugar level may increase (hyperglycaemia).

data.Element: - If you are not eating enough your blood sugar level may become too low (hypoglycaemia).
data.Text: -        If you are not eating enough your blood sugar level may become too low (hypoglycaemia).

data.Element: In most cases you will need a doctor. Make sure that you contact a doctor early.
data.Text: In most cases you will need a doctor. Make sure that you contact a doctor early.

data.Element: If you have type 1 diabetes (insulin dependent diabetes mellitus), do not stop your insulin and continue to get enough carbohydrates. Always tell people who are caring for you or treating you that you require insulin.
data.Text: If you have type 1 diabetes (insulin dependent diabetes mellitus), do not stop your insulin and continue to get enough carbohydrates. Always tell people who are caring for you or treating you that you require insulin.

data.Element: Insulin treatment can cause the body to produce antibodies to insulin (substances that act against insulin). However, only very rarely, this will require a change to your insulin dose.
data.Text: Insulin treatment can cause the body to produce antibodies to insulin (substances that act against insulin). However, only very rarely, this will require a change to your insulin dose.

data.Element: Some patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus and heart disease or previous stroke who were treated with pioglitazone and insulin experienced the development of heart failure. Inform your doctor as soon as possible if you experience signs of heart failure such as unusual shortness of breath or rapid increase in weight or localised swelling (oedema).
data.Text: Some patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus and heart disease or previous stroke who were treated with pioglitazone and insulin experienced the development of heart failure. Inform your doctor as soon as possible if you experience signs of heart failure such as unusual shortness of breath or rapid increase in weight or localised swelling (oedema).
Insulin mix-ups

data.Element: You must always check the pack and the insulin label before each injection to avoid mix-ups between ABASAGLAR and other insulins.
data.Text: You must always check the pack and the insulin label before each injection to avoid mix-ups between ABASAGLAR and other insulins.
Children

data.Element: There is no experience with the use of ABASAGLAR in children below the age of 2 years.
data.Text: There is no experience with the use of ABASAGLAR in children below the age of 2 years.
Other medicines and ABASAGLAR

data.Element: Some medicines cause changes in the blood sugar level (decrease, increase or both depending on the situation). In each case, it may be necessary to adjust your insulin dose to avoid blood sugar levels that are either too low or too high. Be careful when you start or stop taking another medicine.
data.Text: Some medicines cause changes in the blood sugar level (decrease, increase or both depending on the situation). In each case, it may be necessary to adjust your insulin dose to avoid blood sugar levels that are either too low or too high. Be careful when you start or stop taking another medicine.

data.Element: Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are taking, have recently taken or might take any other medicines. Before taking a medicine ask your doctor if it can affect your blood sugar level and what action, if any, you need to take.
data.Text: Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are taking, have recently taken or might take any other medicines. Before taking a medicine ask your doctor if it can affect your blood sugar level and what action, if any, you need to take.

data.Element: Medicines that may cause your blood sugar level to fall (hypoglycaemia) include:
data.Text: Medicines that may cause your blood sugar level to fall (hypoglycaemia) include:

data.Element: - all other medicines to treat diabetes,

data.Text: -        angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors (used to treat certain heart conditions or high blood pressure),

data.Text: -        disopyramide (used to treat certain heart conditions),

data.Text: -        fluoxetine (used to treat depression),

data.Element: - fibrates (used to lower high levels of blood lipids),
data.Text: -        fibrates (used to lower high levels of blood lipids),

data.Element: - monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors (used to treat depression),
data.Text: -        monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors (used to treat depression),

data.Element: - pentoxifylline, propoxyphene, salicylates (such as aspirin, used to relieve pain and lower fever),
data.Text: -        pentoxifylline, propoxyphene, salicylates (such as aspirin, used to relieve pain and lower fever),

data.Text: Medicines that may cause your blood sugar level to rise (hyperglycaemia) include:

data.Text: -        corticosteroids (such as "cortisone" used to treat inflammation),

data.Element: - danazol (medicine acting on ovulation),
data.Text: -        danazol (medicine acting on ovulation),

data.Element: - diazoxide (used to treat high blood pressure),
data.Text: -        diazoxide (used to treat high blood pressure),

data.Element: - diuretics (used to treat high blood pressure or excessive fluid retention),
data.Text: -        diuretics (used to treat high blood pressure or excessive fluid retention),

data.Element: - glucagon (pancreas hormone used to treat severe hypoglycaemia),
data.Text: -        glucagon (pancreas hormone used to treat severe hypoglycaemia),

data.Text: -        isoniazid (used to treat tuberculosis),

data.Text: -        phenothiazine derivatives (used to treat psychiatric disorders),
-        somatropin (growth hormone),
